## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
summary(cars)
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.


## Load libraries
```{r}
library(tidyverse)
library(gridExtra)

```

## Read in data
```{r}

tidyData <- read.csv("chemistry-data-tidy.csv")

```

```{r}
glimpse(tidyData)

```
```{r}

summary(tidyData)

```
```{r}
tidyData$Weeks <- as.factor(tidyData$Weeks)
glimpse(tidyData)
```
 
Renaming columns so they're easier to write.
```{r}

tidyData<- tidyData %>% 
  rename(
   "NH4 (mg/l)" = NH4..mg.l.,
   "TON (mg/l)" = TON..mg.l.,
   "K (ppm)" = K..ppm.,
   "NO2 (mg/l)" = NO2..mg.l.,
   "NO3 (mg/l)" = NO3..mg.l.,
   "Conductivity (mV)" = Conductivity..mV.,
   "Moisture (%)" = Moisture....
  )

head(tidyData)


```


## Make frequency historgrams
```{r}

for (i in 3:9) {
  plot1 <- ggplot(tidyData, aes(tidyData[,i])) +
    geom_histogram() +
    labs(x = colnames(tidyData[i]))
  print(plot1)
  
}
```


## Make boxplots
```{r}

for(i in 3:9){
  plot <- ggplot(tidyData, aes(x = Treatment, y = tidyData[,i], fill = Weeks)) +
          geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.5) + 
          ylab(colnames(tidyData[i])) +
          labs(fill = "Time (weeks)" ) +
          theme(panel.background = element_rect(fill = NA, colour = 'black')) +
          scale_y_continuous(limits = c(min(tidyData[,i]), max(tidyData[,i])))
 print(plot)
 ggsave(file = paste0("boxplot_", colnames(tidyData[i]), ".png"), plot = plot)
}

#grid.arrange(grobs = plots, ncol = 2)

```
